list_definition.definition: to continue to have, use, remember etc; to keep in one’s possession, memory etc

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He finds it difficult to retain information
These dishes don’t retain heat very well.

list_definition.definition: to hold (something) back or keep (something) in its place

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: This wall was built to retain the water from the river in order to prevent flooding.

list_ex_of_english: As once essentially residential communities matured, politicians sought to raise their tax revenues whilst retaining small-scale, almost village life, within an increasingly urbanized milieu.
How were scholars to live in the world while retaining an otherworldly image?
We retained these items, however, because we wanted to compare the relative influence of family violence on an array of social dimensions including network size.
The samples from a1 to f1 retain a midline orientation that features tongue retraction.
These findings indicate that beginning readers retained some visual orthographic features of words in memory even after a 3-day delay.
At what rate do learners learn and retain new vocabulary from reading a graded reader?
Whatever its precise nature, however, protolanguage and the other languages that eventually evolved would, forever after, retain some of that melody.
Authors should retain a copy of the original manuscript.
